metadata.title: The Journal of Negro history, Vol. 3, nos.1-4 (1918)
metadata.sortAs: Journal of Negro history, Vol. 3, nos.1-4 (1918), The
metadata.description: 'The Journal of Negro History' was one of the first scholarly journals to document African-American history. It was founded in January 1916 by Carter G. Woodson, an African-American scholar and journalist. The journal was and still is being published by the Association for the Study of African American Life and History, an organization also founded by Woodson. The journal was the dominant scholarly source for the study of African American history at the time of its founding, simply because there were no other such resources. The journal gave black scholars the chance to publish articles examining African-American history and culture while also documenting the contemporary black experience in the United States. While the journal mainly published the work of black authors and encouraged their academic success, it was also an outlet for white scholars who had different views regarding black history than their counterparts. The title of the journal was changed to 'The Journal of African American History' in 1926 and, as mentioned above, is still being published. The journal was published quarterly; it comprises scholarly articles, documents, book reviews and notes.  [Source: Wikipedia and book]

publisher.name: Assn. for the Study of Negro Life and History, Inc.

metadata.title: American Poetry, 1922: A Miscellany
metadata.description: Selected works from various American poets, including Amy Lowell, Robert Frost, Carl Sandburg, Sara Teasdale, Edna St. Vincent Millay and others.

metadata.title: How to Do It
metadata.description:
Edward Everett Hale (1822-1909) was an American author, historian, and Unitarian minister, best known for his writings such as "The Man Without a Country", published in Atlantic Monthly, in support of the Union during the Civil War. He was the grand-nephew of Nathan Hale, the American spy during the Revolutionary War.

Hale was a child prodigy who exhibited extraordinary literary skills. He graduated from Boston Latin School at age 13 and attended Harvard College immediately after. There, he settled in with the literary set, won two Bowdoin Prizes, and was elected the Class Poet. He graduated second in his class in 1839 and then studied at Harvard Divinity School.--Wikipedia.

metadata.title: The Nursery: A Monthly Magazine for Youngest Readers. August 1877, Vol. XXII, No. 2.
metadata.sortAs: Nursery: A Monthly Magazine for Youngest Readers. August 1877, Vol. XXII, No. 2., The
metadata.description: The Nursery was a 19th-century American "magazine for youngest readers", edited by Fanny P. Seaverns. The Nursery began publishing in 1867. It appears to have ceased publication in 1881.  [Source: University of Pennsylvania]

metadata.title: Thirteen Chapters of American History represented by the Edward Moran series of Thirteen Historical Marine Paintings
metadata.sortAs: Thirteen Chapters of American History represented by the Edward Moran series of Thirteen Historical Marine Paintings
metadata.description:
The Thirteen Paintings, to a history and description of which (and incidentally to a brief memoir of their creator, Edward Moran) these pages are devoted, are monumental in their character and importance. Mr. Moran designated them as representing the 'Marine History of the United States.' I have somewhat changed this title; for even the untraversed 'Ocean' and the landing of Columbus in the new world represent periods which necessarily affect the whole American Continent.

The conception of these pictures was in itself a mark of genius, for no more fitting subjects could have been chosen by the greatest marine painter in the United States than the heroic and romantic incidents connected with the sea, which are so splendidly depicted in these thirteen grand paintings.

The production of these paintings was the result of a patriotic and noble impulse on the part of the artist, through which he has immortalized the maritime achievements of our country, and for which we, as well as future generations, can hardly be sufficiently grateful!

metadata.title: Tradition Through Modernity
metadata.subtitle: Postmodernism and the Nation-State in Folklore Scholarship
metadata.description:
In their study of social practices deemed traditional, scholars tend to use the concept and idea of tradition as an element of meaning in the practices under investigation. But just whose meaning is it? Is it a meaning generated by those who study tradition or those whose traditions are being studied? In both cases, particular criteria for traditionality are employed, whether these are explicated or not. Individuals and groups will no doubt continue to uphold their traditional practices or refer to their practices as traditional. While they are in no way obliged to explicate in analytical terms their criteria for traditionality, the same cannot be said for those who make the study of traditions their profession. In scholarly analysis, traditions need to be explained instead of used as explanations for apparent repetitions and replications or symbolic linking in social practice, values, history, and heritage politics.

This book takes a closer look at ‘tradition’ and ‘folklore’ in order to conceptualize them within discourses on modernity and modernism. The first section discusses ‘modern’ and ‘traditional’ as modern concepts and the study of folklore as a modern trajectory. The underlying tenet here is that non-modernity cannot be represented without modern mediation, which therefore makes the representations of non-modernity epistemologically modern. The second section focuses on the nation-state of Finland and the nationalistic use of folk traditions in the discursive production of Finnish modernity and its Others. The insights are applicable worldwide in discussions on cultural representation.

metadata.title: Altruism Its Nature and Varieties
metadata.description:
This is a Project Guttenberg  edition released in 2018.
*Altruism: Its Nature and Varieties* by George Herbert Palmer explores the philosophical and moral foundations of altruistic behavior. Palmer examines the motivations behind selfless acts and distinguishes different forms of altruism, from instinctive kindness to principled ethical conduct. Drawing on examples from literature, history, and daily life, he offers a thoughtful analysis of how altruism shapes human relationships and society, encouraging readers to reflect on the deeper values that guide compassionate action.

metadata.title: The Corner House Girls in a Play How they rehearsed, how they acted, and what the play brought in
metadata.sortAs: Corner House Girls in a Play How they rehearsed, how they acted, and what the play brought in, The
metadata.description:
Four girls from eight to fourteen years of age receive word that a rich bachelor uncle has died, leaving them the old Corner House he occupied. In this story, the girls perform a play to raise money for a women's hospital.
Grace Brooks Hill was a house pseudonym of the Stratemeyer Syndicate, a publishing company that produced a number of book series for children, including Nancy Drew, The Hardy Boys, the various Tom Swift series, the Bobbsey Twins and others.

metadata.title: A Cruise in the Sky; or, The Legend of the Great Pink Pearl
metadata.sortAs: Cruise in the Sky; or, The Legend of the Great Pink Pearl, A
metadata.description:
Harry Lincoln Sayler (1863-1913) was an American newspaperman and novelist, under his own name and pseudonyms, including as a ghostwriter for a popular youth fiction series. "A Cruise In The Sky; or, The Legend of The Great Pink Pearl" was written under the pen name Ashton Lamar.

Sayler graduated from DePauw University. He married June Elliott of Shelbyville, Indiana in 1889. They had two children. By occupation Sayler was a newsman, starting in 1886 in Indianapolis. By 1889 he was working in Chicago, eventually becoming general manager of the City News Bureau of Chicago. Sayler was interested in history and became a member of the Illinois State Historical Society, the Chicago Historical Association, and the Louisiana Historical Association. He developed an expertise on the subject of pirates.

Sayler wrote three series of juvenile fiction relating to the then-novel technology of airplanes and flight. He wrote the Boy Scouts of the Air series under the pen name Gordon Stuart, the Aeroplane Boys series as Ashton Lamar, and the Airship Boys series under his own name. Sayler also wrote for another juvenile series, the Boys' Big Game series, under the pseudonym Elliott Whitney.--Wikipedia.

metadata.title: Dave Porter's return to school or, winning the medal of honor
metadata.sortAs: Dave Porter's return to school or, winning the medal of honor
metadata.description:
This is the third book in the author's Dave Porter Series, which follows the life of “...a typical American lad, of strong moral qualities” but unknown parentage who attends Oak Hall boarding school. In this volume
Dave is finishing his preparation for college. His friends are still with him, but likewise his enemies. Throughout the challenges he meets in this volume, "...Dave stands up for what is honest and true, and in this his example is well worth following.” [Source: book preface]

metadata.title: The Campfire Girls on Station Island
metadata.sortAs: Campfire Girls on Station Island, The
metadata.subtitle: The Wireless from the Steam Yacht
metadata.description: When their yacht catches on fire, the girls endeavor to use new radio technology to call for help.

metadata.title: The Red Book of Heroes
metadata.description:
With 8 colored plates and numerous illustrations by A. Wallis Mills.--From title page.

Leonora Blanche Lang (1851-1933) was an English writer, editor, and translator. She is best known as the translator, collaborator, and writer of The Fairy Books, a series of 25 collections of folk and fairy tales for children she published with her husband, Andrew Lang, between 1889 and 1913. The best known are the Rainbow Fairy Books, a series of twelve collections of fairy tales each assigned a different color.

The authorship and translation of the Coloured Fairy Books are often and incorrectly attributed to Lang's husband alone. However, as Andrew acknowledges in a preface to The Lilac Fairy Book (1910), "The fairy books have been almost wholly the work of Mrs. Lang, who has translated and adapted them from the French, German, Portuguese, Italian, Spanish, Catalan, and other languages. Lang's other works include a history of Russia translated from the French of Alfred Rambaud (1879) and a novel, Dissolving Views, published in 1884. She was also a frequent reviewer for periodicals such as the Saturday Review and the Academy.--Wikipedia.

metadata.title: The Automobile Girls Along the Hudson
metadata.sortAs: Automobile Girls Along the Hudson, The
metadata.subtitle: Fighting Fire in Sleepy Hollow
metadata.description: Four teenage girls and their chaperone, Miss Sallie, find danger, romance and adventure on a scenic motor trip along the Hudson River.

metadata.title: The Meadow-Brook Girls by the Sea
metadata.sortAs: Meadow-Brook Girls by the Sea, The
metadata.subtitle: The Loss of The Lonesome Bar
metadata.description: Five teenage girls encounter mishaps and mysteries on their summer vacation to Lonesome Cove.

metadata.title: Kutnar, Son of Pic.  Vol. 2
metadata.description:
"Kutnar, Son of Pic" is the second volume of "The Long Ages Ago Series." The first volume was "Pic, the Weapon-Maker."

The story follows Kutnar, a young cave boy, as he navigates the dangerous world of early humans and battles with cave beasts. Alongside his father Pic and their tribe, Kutnar sets out on a journey across the Pyrenees in search of a new home.

Excerpt: "To some, I am known as Pic, the Weapon Maker; to others—but no matter. One name is as good as another. Yes, I am the Mammoth Man." He folded his arms across his broad chest and even as he looked kindly upon his visitor, his eyes as much as said: "Can it be possible that mere curiosity has brought you here to see me? "Gonch did not notice the look of those eyes; he was watching the man himself. Such evidence of physical health and strength, he had never before observed in a human being. "I can see now why they call him the Mammoth Man," he thought to himself. "He is a giant among men as is the Hairy Elephant among beasts." But all he said was: "I helped your boy. Perhaps for that, you can look upon me as a friend."--Google Books.

Illustrated by the author.

metadata.title: Dave Dawson with the Pacific Fleet
metadata.sortAs: Dave Dawson with the Pacific Fleet
metadata.description: Author Robert Sidney Bowen, Jr. (1900–1977) was a World War I aviator, newspaper journalist, magazine editor and writer. He is best known for his boys' series of books written during World War II: the Dave Dawson War Adventure Series (fifteen books written between 1941 and 1946) and the Red Randall Series (eight books  written between 1944 and 1946). In this story, follow Dave Dawson and his pal, English pilot Freddy Farmer, as they execute a secret mission aboard the U.S.S. Indian, bound for the western Pacific. Their assignment is to discover the identity of a Nazi spy working on the ship and foil his plans to disrupt a major Allied attack against the Japanese in the Marshall Islands. [Source: Wikipedia, book]

metadata.title: Marcy, the Refugee
metadata.description: Charles Austin Fosdick (1842–1915), better known by his pen name Harry Castlemon, was a prolific writer of juvenile stories and novels, intended mainly for boys. In this story "...we take up once more the history of the exploits and adventures of our Union hero Marcy Gray, the North Carolina boy, who tried so hard and so unsuccessfully to be 'True to his Colors.' Marcy, as we know, was loyal to the old flag but he had had few opportunities to prove it, until he took his brother, Sailor Jack, out to the Federal blockading fleet in his little schooner Fairy Belle, to give him a chance to enlist in the navy. That was by far the most dangerous undertaking in which Marcy had ever engaged, and at the time of which we write, he had not seen the beginning of the trouble it was destined to bring him." [Source: Wikipedia, book]

metadata.title: Team-Mates
metadata.description: Another boarding school, sports and adventure story from the prolific Ralph Henry Barbour. This time, we meet 14-year-old John ("Cal") Boland, room-mate Ned Brent and the other six boys residing in West House (Sandy, Dutch, Hoop, Spud, Clara and The Fungus), and attending the Oak Park School, a preparatory school for boys. There appears to be a thief in West House; see how his/her identity is revealed. A mix of study, football, hijinks and other adventures occur, in typical Barbour style.

metadata.title: The Silver Maple
metadata.description:
Marian Keith's "The Silver Maple" is a historical novel set in the Canadian backwoods in the early 20th century. It follows the life of a young boy named Scotty MacDonald as he navigates his identity and relationships within a tight-knit Scottish community.--Project Gutenberg.

Mary Esther Miller MacGregor, (1872-1961) also known as Marian Keith, was a Canadian fiction author. In 1906 when she tried to publish her first novel she learned that her own name was in use by another author (Esther Miller), so she chose to write under the pen name Marian Keith. In 1909, she married Donald MacGregor, one of the founding members of the United Church of Canada.

In 1924, she wrote a book called A Gentleman Adventurer, which she based on the life of a neighbor, Thompson Smith. Canadian literary scholars have cited this as her best work. In many of her novels, MacGregor sought to portray her connection between religious thought and social conscience to improve life for the poor and uneducated.--Wikipedia.

metadata.title: The Red Cross Girls on the French Firing Line
metadata.sortAs: Red Cross Girls on the French Firing Line, The
metadata.description: Margaret O'Bannon Womack Vandercook (1877-1958) was an American writer of children's literature. She did not become a professional writer until after her husband's death in 1908, but became known as "the queen of Camp Fire writers", authoring twenty-one Camp Fire novels under her own name as well as under the pseudonym "Margaret Love Sanderson."  In addition to the Camp Fire Girls series, Vandercook was known for her other series of "Girls" books which include the Ranch Girls series, Red Cross Girls series, and Girl Scouts series. This book is the second in her Red Cross Girls series--ten books written between 1916 and 1920--that describe the experiences of young women volunteers working to assist soldiers in various capacities during World War I. This volume takes these volunteers very close to the fighting, but does not describe the horrors of conflict in explicit detail. [sources: Wikipedia, Goodreads]

metadata.title: The Red Cross Girls with the Russian Army
metadata.sortAs: Red Cross Girls with the Russian Army, The
metadata.description: Margaret O'Bannon Womack Vandercook (1877-1958) was an American writer of children's literature. This book is the fourth in her Red Cross Girls series--ten books written between 1916 and 1920--that describe the experiences of young women volunteers working to assist soldiers in various capacities during World War I. This volume takes these volunteers very close to the fighting, but does not describe the horrors of conflict in explicit detail. [sources: Wikipedia, Goodreads]

metadata.title: Frank in the Woods
metadata.description: Charles Austin Fosdick (1842–1915), better known by his pen name Harry Castlemon, was a prolific writer of juvenile stories and novels, intended mainly for boys. 'Frank in the Woods' is the third in a series of juvenile action-adventure tales featuring up-for-anything Frank, his loyal sidekick Archie, and pals George and Harry. In this installment, the four find themselves in a cozy winter encampment by the lake, unaware of the thrills and dangers that lie ahead. [Sources: Wikipedia, Goodreads]

metadata.title: Harper's Round Table, November 12, 1895 (v.XVII, no.837)
metadata.description: This is an issue of a weekly magazine that succeeded the earlier 'Harper's Young People', which began in November of 1879 as an illustrated 16-page magazine that contained fiction and non-fiction works and was advertised as being appropriate for boys and girls ages six to sixteen. It was renamed 'Harper's Round Table' and it's target audience switched to a slightly older demographic at the end of April 1895. Many of its fictional pieces are serialized. 'Harper's Round Table' ceased publication in 1899. (Source: Wikipedia)

metadata.title: Man on the Ocean
metadata.subtitle: A Book about Boats and Ships
metadata.description: This is a history of boat and shipbuilding, written for older boys from a particularly British and decidedly Christian perspective. Illustrated with black and white drawings by Robert Richardson. R[obert] M[ichael] Ballantyne (1825-1894) was a Scottish writer, primarily of juvenile fiction, who authored more than 100 books. He was also an accomplished artist, exhibiting some of his water-color paintings at the Royal Scottish Academy.

metadata.title: How Girls Can Help Their Country
metadata.sortAs: How Girls Can Help Their Country
metadata.description: The first official handbook of the Girl Scouts, adapted by Juliette Low from the Girl Guide Handbook created by Agnes Baden-Powell and Sir Robert Baden-Powell.  Includes laws, membership qualifications, tests for merit badges, and activities.

metadata.description: This is an issue of a weekly magazine that succeeded the earlier 'Harper's Young People', which began in November of 1879 as an illustrated 16-page magazine that contained fiction and non-fiction works and was advertised as being appropriate for boys and girls ages six to sixteen. It was renamed 'Harper's Round Table' and it's target audience switched to a slightly older demographic at the end of April 1895. Many of its fictional pieces serialized. 'Harper's Round Table' ceased publication in 1899. (Source: Wikipedia)

metadata.title: Ninja Baby
metadata.description: From the day she was born, Nina was a ninja baby. She obliterated her applesauce. She concealed herself at bath time. And she was training herself in advanced infiltration (of movie night). Nina wants to do everything by herself, until the day her parents bring home a Kung Fu Master (a baby brother). Now with a sibling, Nina will face the one thing she cannot do alone: be part of a family. With verve and humor, David Zeltser and Diane Goode tell the story of an unusually gifted child, and the family that is more than a match for her. Plus, this is the fixed format version, which will look almost identical to the print version. Additionally for devices that support audio, this ebook includes a read-along setting.

metadata.title: July Jitters
metadata.subtitle: July Jitters
metadata.description:
It's a mystery every month from popular A to Z Mysteries author Ron Roy! With the younger siblings of the A to Z Mysteries kids!
July is for Jitters...

In the seventh book of the Calendar Mysteries - an early chapter book mystery series - the mayor is having a special Fourth of July contest; the person whose pet has the best Independence Day costume gets to be mayor for a day! Bradly, Brian, Nate, and Lucy transform Polly the pony into Thomas Jefferson and Pal the dog into the Declaration of Independence. But when the pet parade rolls around, the animals are nowhere to be found! Maybe they have stage fright. Can the kids find their dressed-up pets and calm them down betfore the Fourth of July fun begins?
Parents, teachers, and librarians agree that these highly collectible chapter books are pefect for emerging readers and any kid who loves mysteries!

imprint.name: Random House Books for Young Readers

metadata.title: Run…It's a Bee!
metadata.description: As Victoria and Jasper were enjoying their new sunflower, Jasper gets pollen on his nose. A bee soon arrives which sends the characters running. As they run through a baseball game screaming, Run, it's a Bee, all the players start to follow them, as they run through the school auditorium screaming, Run, it's a Bee, all the actors start following them. When they finally arrive back at their garden the bee lands on Jasper's nose and licks the pollen off. He soon proceeds on his way leaving the characters feeling silly that the bee never wanted to sting them, he just wanted the pollen!

metadata.title: 100 Cupboards (100 Cupboards Book 1)
metadata.description:
Readers who love Percy Jackson, the Unwanteds, and Beyonders will discover that 100 cupboards mean 100 opportunities for adventure! The bestselling and highly acclaimed 100 Cupboards series starts here.
 
What dangers are locked behind the cupboard doors? Henry isn’t brave, but when he hears a thumping and scratching on the other side of his bedroom wall, he can’t ignore it. He scrapes off the plaster and discovers mysterious doors—cupboards of all different shapes and sizes. Through one he sees a glowing room and a man strolling back and forth. Through another he sees only darkness and feels the cold sense that something isn’t right. When his cousin Henrietta boldly travels into the worlds beyond the cupboards, it’s up to Henry to follow her. Now that he’s opened the doors, can he keep the evil inside from coming through?
 
"A must-read series." —The Washington Post

metadata.title: The Nose that Knows
metadata.description: When Milo's knowing nose finds a scent it likes, nothing will stop it. Nose to the ground, Milo is led anywhere and everywhere – out the door, through the park, up a skyscraper and even to outer space! But will Milo's nose ever lead him home? Follow Milo the dog as he follows his nose in this funny yet sweet rhyme from Malachy Doyle, author of Peek a Book and I Love You When, and illustrated by artist Barroux.

metadata.title: Boardwalk Adventure
metadata.description: In this full color storybook, Dora the Explorer and her best friend Boots go to the boardwalk for a carnival! This Nickelodeon Read-Along contains audio narration.

metadata.title: The Secret of the Mansion
metadata.subtitle: Trixie Belden Series, Book 1
metadata.description:
Trixie Belden first appeared more than 50 years ago in The Secret of the Mansion, which was followed by 38 more adventures as generations of readers grew up with teenage detective Trixie and her mystery-solving friends. Now, Trixie is back with a fresh look and ready to charm a new band of sleuths!
Trixie Belden is bracing for one boring summer. Her lucky older brothers are away at camp, so she is stuck babysitting. But when a new girl, Honey, moves in down the road, Trixie finally has the chance to make a best friend—and Honey isn't the only fresh face in town.
The girls spy someone inside a nearby house, which is curious because Trixie knows her grumpy old neighbor, Mr. Frayne, is sick at the hospital. There's only one reason why someone would go poking around Mr. Frayne's run-down manor. They must be looking for the fortune that is said to be hidden on the property. But that's only a rumor...right?
Trixie wished for an adventure, and she might just get her most exciting summer yet!

imprint.name: Random House Books for Young Readers

metadata.title: The United States in World War II
metadata.sortAs: United States in World War II, The
metadata.subtitle: 1941–1945
metadata.description:
History is dramatic—and the renowned, award-winning authors Christopher Collier and James Lincoln Collier demonstrate this in a compelling series aimed at young readers. Covering American history from the founding of Jamestown through present day, these volumes explore far beyond the dates and events of a historical chronicle to present a moving illumination of the ideas, opinions, attitudes, and tribulations that led to the birth of this great nation.

The United States in World War II provides background on American sentiments prior to US involvement in the war. The authors contend that it may have played out differently if some countries, including the US, had been prepared and/or willing to become involved sooner. Fascist ideology is defined.

belongsTo.name: The Drama of American History Series

metadata.title: Curious George and the Birthday Surprise
metadata.sortAs: Curious George and the Birthday Surprise
metadata.description:
When the man with the yellow hat tells George that he is planning a surprise, of course George is curious. Before long George finds a hat, noisemakers, decorations, and games. It must be a birthday! But whose birthday is it? That's the surprise!

The audio for this Read-Aloud ebook was produced and engineered by Perry Geyer at Cybersound Recording Studios (349 Newbury St., Ste. 201, Boston, MA 02115). Music theme composed by Cybersound Studios (Perry Geyer, Silvio Amato, Michael Africk, Greg Hawkes). Engineers: Perry Geyer (music production and sound design), Rob Whitaker (editing and mixing engineer), Samuel Creager (editing, sound design, and mixing engineer), Marcus Clark, Corey Rupp. Assistant engineers: Dave Chapman, Mike Pekarski, Justin Sheriff, Daniel Wrigley, Andrew Sardinha, Mami Ienaga, Kevin Notar, Maria Goulamhoussen. Sheridan Willard, John Huang, John Schmidt. Voiceover by Joyce Kulhawik.

metadata.title: Franklin's New Friend, Franklin's Bad Day, and Franklin Has a Sleepover
metadata.sortAs: Franklin's New Friend, Franklin's Bad Day, and Franklin Has a Sleepover
metadata.subtitle: Three Classic Franklin Stories
metadata.description: Franklin's New Friend Franklin has always lived in the same house in the same town, and he's grown up with the same friends. In this Franklin Classic Storybook, new neighbors move in—the Moose family! At school, Mr. Owl asks Franklin to be Moose's buddy. Initially, Franklin is afraid of Moose because of his size but he soon realizes that despite their differences, he has made a new friend. Franklin's Bad Day Since Franklin's friend Otter moved away, nothing seems to go right—until Franklin figures out a way he and Otter can stay friends. Another Franklin Classic Storybook to delight young readers. Franklin Has a Sleepover In this Franklin Classic Storybook, Franklin can't wait for his best friend Bear to come over for their first sleepover. However, when it's time for bed, Bear begins to miss his own room—until Franklin comes up with an idea to make Bear feel more comfortable. This fixed-layout ebook, which preserves the design and layout of the original print book, features read-along narration by the author as well as music and sound effects.

metadata.title: Bunny Loves to Learn
metadata.description: Buster is excited about a project he and his friends get to do in class. But his friend Max can't decide what to present, and Max starts to run out of time. He needs some help from his friends, and Buster thinks he has a great idea for him!Read along to the story as Buster and his friends explore history and dress up in costumes for a special classroom show-and-tell...and find out what Max decides to do! Parragon is the largest illustrated non-fiction publisher in the world and a global leader in innovative digital books for children in many languages. Welcome to the world of Parragon!

metadata.title: Curious George's Dream
metadata.description: After a long day at the fair George is frustrated. It seems he is always too small! But when George falls asleep and wakes up BIG, he discovers being too large can be difficult, too, and maybe he's the right size after all. This ebook includes audio narration.

metadata.title: Chicken Little
metadata.description: "I think the sky is falling! I must run and tell the king!" Chicken Little fears the sky is falling, so he runs with his friends to tell the king. But who do they meet along the way? Parragon is the largest illustrated non-fiction publisher in the world and a global leader in innovative digital books for children in many languages. Welcome to the world of Parragon!

metadata.title: The Dragon's Eye
metadata.description:
For the first time ever, DRAGONOLOGY fiction! Introducing the Dragonology Chronicles — full-length novels with enough fire-breathing adventure to satisfy true Dragonology fans who just can't get enough!



Adventure! Villains! And dragons, dragons, dragons! From the creators of the best-selling Dragonology series, this first volume of the Dragonology Chronicles finds Daniel Cook and his sister, Beatrice, studying with eccentric dragonologist Dr. Ernest Drake. Soon they’re caught up in a race to find the stolen Dragon’s Eye — a jewel that has the power to reflect the true Dragon Master — before it is stolen by the evil Ignatius Crook. Working with Dr. Drake (and many friendly dragons), can these young siblings foil Ignatius and recover the Dragon’s Eye?
